description.plain:
Russell Tyrone Jones (November 15, 1968 – November 13, 2004) was an American rapper and occasional producer, who went by the stage names Ol' Dirty Bastard (ODB), Ason Unique, Osirus, Rainman, Big Baby Jesus, and Dirt McGirt. He was one of the founding members of the Wu-Tang Clan, a rap group primarily from Staten Island, New York that first rose to mainstream prominence with their 1993 debut album Enter the Wu-Tang: 36 Chambers.

Ol' Dirty Bastard’s wildly erratic behavior was the result of serious drug problems or genuine mental instability.

ODB’s rhymes have stood the one true test and that is the test of time. They are funny, concise and always memorable

RIP ODB

songs.title: Shimmy Shimmy Ya

description.plain:
Waiter – “How would you like your steak”

Ol' Dirty Bastard – “Oh baby, I like it rawwwww”

“Shimmy Shimmy Ya” was released as the second single off of Return to the 36 Chambers: The Dirty Version. It went on to become ODB’s most famous song and has been sampled in various songs as well as found its way into hit shows such as Breaking Bad.

Off on a natural charge, bon-voyage
Yeah, from the home of the Dodger Brooklyn squad
Wu-Tang killer bees on a swarm
Rain on your college-ass disco dorm
For you to even touch my skill
You gotta go through one killer bee and he aim for the kill now
Chop that down, pass it all around

songs.full_title: Brooklyn Zoo by Ol' Dirty Bastard
songs.title: Brooklyn Zoo

description.plain:
This self-produced tirade against an unnamed adversary was Ol Dirty’s first solo release, and the first true indication of the man’s potential.

While “Shimmy Shimmy Ya” went on to become a much bigger single, “Brooklyn Zoo” was always the b-boy favourite and remains a certified Wu-banger to this day.

description.plain:
Ol' Dirty is a pimp in the literal sense: the verses focus on how awesome he is while the chorus serves to assure us that O.D.B.’s female employees never short him.

The video to this song includes clips from the 1975 blaxploitation film Dolemite.

songs.artist_names: Ol' Dirty Bastard (Ft. Brooklyn Zu & Sunz of Man)
songs.full_title: Protect Ya Neck II the Zoo by Ol' Dirty Bastard (Ft. Brooklyn Zu & Sunz of Man)
songs.title: Protect Ya Neck II the Zoo
songs.title_with_featured: Protect Ya Neck II the Zoo (Ft. Brooklyn Zu & Sunz of Man)

description.plain:
A posse cut of epic proportions. The Sunz Of Man and the Brooklyn Zu are two very well known groups from the Wu-Tang Killa Beez.

Each of the members of the Sunz Of Man have gone on to have a solo career respectable in the underground aside from 60 Sec who dropped his debut album in 2010.

While the Brooklyn Zu are undoubtedly less well known, they came up in the exact same era and sadly it took them until 2008 to release a group album – none of the members aside from the de-facto leader the Buddha Monk have released solo albums.

The two groups are the most respected of the Killa Beez along with Killarmy, so for ODB to have all of the members from both groups on one song is a feat in itself.

The beat is produced by RZA.

The title of the track is a reference to the original Wu posse cut that started it all.

[Verse 1: Killah Priest]

Owahhaerahh

YO! SHOW THESE MOTHERFUCKERS WHAT TIME IT IS
[Number two, the snake] Rawwrarrrah
Rahhwarwaahauh, rawwaroar!!

songs.full_title: Damage by Ol' Dirty Bastard (Ft. GZA)
songs.title: Damage

description.plain:
On the 7th Track from Dirty’s debut solo record, Return To The 36 Chambers: The Dirty Version, he and cousin / fellow Wu-Tang member, GZA, trade bars over a simplistic, yet sinister RZA beat, co produced by 4th Disciple.

This track has great chemistry between Genius and Dirty, as expected. The two had previously freestyled in 1991, with GZA rapping and Dirty beatboxing.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2PyXtdZxEss

songs.full_title: Wastin' Time (No More) by Ol' Dirty Bastard
songs.title: Wastin’ Time (No More)

description.plain:
An unreleased song by Ol' Dirty Bastard. The song is about the time Dirty wasted on drugs, women and jail. Recorded in 2003 or 2004 after he was released from prison and signed to the Roc Nation. Another intepretation of the lyrics is that the song is a farewell song by ODB to his fans, friends and family.

The producer of this song is unknown, but the sample flip is from Billy Joel’s “The Stranger”, a popularly sampled song which you can hear on other tracks such as “For No Reason” by Freestyle Fellowship and “The Foundation” by Xzibit.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bnlvPoDU5LY

Russell Tyrone Jones: May his soul rest in eternal peace…

songs.full_title: Goin' Down by Ol' Dirty Bastard
songs.title: Goin’ Down

description.plain:
10th song off this album. At the beginning, we can hear ODB recalling a game he used to play as a child. During the song, we hear him rhyming about who he is, how he’s known all over the world and even his way to flirt with girls along with his usual crazy flow. In the middle of the song we can hear his wife Icelene Jones arguing with him. His answer to that it’s song for all of us: ‘Over the Rainbow’ by Judy Garland. ODB’s wife and the RZA gave more insight about this song on the mini documentary called ‘Ol’ Dirty Bastard and the Legacy of 'Return to the 36 Chambers’, released to celebrate the 25th anniversary of ODB’s classic album.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-lRkilfKtRM

(see 11:58)

songs.full_title: Brooklyn Zoo II by Ol' Dirty Bastard (Ft. Ghostface Killah)
songs.title: Brooklyn Zoo II

description.plain:
A song off of ODB’s debut album the song is half studio and the final half is ODB spitting wisdom on stage.

Fellow Wu-Tang MC Ghostface Killah has a guest verse and the beat is laced by RZA.

ODB’s verse was previously used on “Damage” featuring GZA but the beauty of Dirty’s flow is that no matter how many times he spat the same verse he always switched it up and it always sounded fresh and dope even if you’d heard the rhymes before.

There really was no father to his style and he will always be remembered as one of the greats.

songs.full_title: Cuttin' Headz by Ol' Dirty Bastard (Ft. RZA)
songs.title: Cuttin’ Headz

description.plain:
This track features and is produced by Wu-Tang member RZA. Throughout the song, Ol' Dirty Bastard and RZA spit lines back and forth creating a final verse mixed with both rappers.
This song featured on the unreleased 1992 Wu-Tang demo.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eN-CtvKkVeo

The piano and drum loops in this track are the same as “Clan In Da Front”. The drums are sampled from the Hip Hop favourite, “Synthetic Substitution”, and the piano comes from Theolonius Monk’s “Ba-Lue Bolivar Ba-Lues-Are”.

songs.full_title: Drunk Game (Sweet Sugar Pie) by Ol' Dirty Bastard
songs.title: Drunk Game (Sweet Sugar Pie)

description.plain:
A comical track, which consists of ODB screaming and rambling like a drunkard, spitting game (the act of picking up/ arousing a girl) to a girl, which explains the first half of the title. We can see towards the end of the song that he was quite successful.

ODB has multiple children (7-13 kids), many from different mothers, meaning sex isn’t a unfamiliar concept to him. It could be said that these lyrics are somewhat similar to what Dirty would actually say to women when trying to pick them up. (Hopefully minus the orgasmic tirade towards the end.)

Ethan Ryman produces this track, but no others in Return to The 36 Chambers.

description.plain: This song is from the posthumous mixtape album, Osirus, released in 2005. Ol' Dirty Bastard (ODB) signed with Roc-a-Fella Records after two years in jail,  on the day of his release. He died less than a year later of drug overdose. This album was never officially released.

songs.title: Pop Shit

description.plain:
This ‘The Neptunes’ track produced in 2002 was featured by legendary Wu-Tang Clan rapper and co-founder Ol' Dirty Bastard.

Studio footage from the recording session shows a humble side of ODB, asking Pharrell to do the final singing touches to the song, which is not really what the producer had in mind.

songs.full_title: Thirsty by Ol' Dirty Bastard (Ft. Black Keith)
songs.title: Thirsty

description.plain:
Thirsty by Ol' Dirty Bastard & Black Keith is a chill party song on one hand, and the soundtrack to Blade: Trinity on the other.
It’s a song about alcohol, and being addicted to it. Of course, with alcohol comes party, about which ODB raps in his 12 bar verse. As with various alcohol addiction songs, it’s overall feel is very dark.

ODB raps relatively little in this song, allowing  Black Keith to sing a tune that can stay stuck in your head for days.

Thirsty appeared on the Blade: Trinity Soundtrack Album, which was released November 23, 2004. Therefore it was released 10 days after the tragic death of Big Baby Jesus. R.I.P

songs.full_title: Cold Blooded by Ol' Dirty Bastard
songs.title: Cold Blooded

description.plain:
“Cold Blooded” is the third track of N– Please, second solo studio album by Wu-Tang Clan member Ol' Dirty Bastard, released in 1999.

The track is an officially approved cover of the original song by the eclectic musician Rick James, even though ODB, who sings over an electronic and funky beat by The Neptunes, makes his rendition even more hilarious, adding a funny and explicit rap verse and screaming at the top of his lungs throughout the track, so much that he almost makes the microphone break.

songs.full_title: Taking a Shit by Ol' Dirty Bastard
songs.title: Taking a Shit

description.plain:
This is Ol' Dirty Bastard being quite…a dirty bastard in an interlude off of Trials & Tribulations Of Russel Jones. However it has a much deeper meaning than the what see superficially.

Ol' Dirty Bastard has made it from the hood through several hardships, and now he’s using an extremely fancy and nice looking bathroom, one  which he could never have had handed to him. The bathroom is a symbol of making it through to the upperclass.

He’s not accustomed to this because he’s still hood in his heart, that’s why he’s unused to the protective covers on the toilet seat and this simple task of using the bathroom is a problem for him.
